context: Loudoun, a capable administrator but a cautious field commander, planned <a0_3>one major operation<a0_3/> for 1757: <a0_1><a0_2><a0_4>an <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>attack on New France's capital, Quebec<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_4/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. Leaving a sizable force at Fort William Henry <a1_0><a1_4><b6_0>to <a1_1><a1_2><a1_3>distract Montcalm<b6_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, he began organizing for the expedition to Quebec. He was then ordered by <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><a2_4><b7_0>William Pitt<b7_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, the Secretary of State responsible for the colonies, to attack Louisbourg first. Beset by delays of all kinds, the expedition was finally ready to sail from Halifax, Nova Scotia in early August. In the meantime French ships had escaped the British blockade of the French coast, and a fleet outnumbering the British one awaited Loudoun at Louisbourg. Faced with this strength, Loudoun <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><a3_4><b8_0>returned to New York<b8_0/><a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/> amid news that a massacre had occurred at Fort William Henry.
